MEMBERS OF THE BOARD Antii McMULLEN - Governor CHARLES W. POOL -..Secretary of State GEORGE W. MARSH - ....State Auditor C. D. ROBINSON State Treasurer T. E. WILLIAMS ____... State Tax Commissioner TAX COMMISSIONERS OF NEBRASKA The position of State Tax Commissioner was created by the constitu - tion of 1920. Prior thereto the -work was performed by a secretary to the State Board of Equalization and Assessment, the Tax Commissioner being majde a member of the board. Those who have served as Com - missioner under the constitutional provision are: NAME COUNTY SERVED W. H. OSBORNE WM. H. SMITH T. E. WILLIAMS Custer Seward April 18, 192S, to Jan. 12. 1925 April 25, 1921, to April 18, 1923 Hamilton Jan. 12, 1925. to

LETTER OF TRAN8MITTAL November 30th, 1925 Hon. Adam Me Mull en, Governor of Nebraska, Lincoln. My dear Sir: Herewith is transmitted the annual report of this department for the year 1925. In doing so I want to express the appreciation of the depart - ment for the co-operation of yourself and the other members of the State Board of Equalization and Assessment. I also want to express my thanks to the County Assessors and County Clerks of the state for their help, and to the other county officers upon whom it has been necessary to make frequent calls for co-operation. Tours very truly, T. E. WILLIAMS, State Tax Commissioner.

104 REPORT OF TAX COMMISSIONER STATEMENT NO. 5 State Levy for the year 1926 The following resolution fixing the State Levy for 1925 was unanimous - ly adopted by the State Board of Equalization and Assessment on August 3, 1925. WHEREAS From the Auditor's Statement, which is attached hereto, it appears that it is necessary to raise for the expenses of the State Government for the current fiscal year the sum of $6,238,399.19, which includes $136,106.04 appropriated for the expense of the 1923 legislature and not heretofore levied, and for the payment of deficiency claims arising during prior years and allowed by the Legislature as claims against the general fund of th« state the sum of $462,893.76. The assessed valuation of ail tangible property of the state for 1925 is $3,159,385,767. It is estimated that the Class A Intangible property $70,772,861, and the Class B Intangible Property, $80,869,641, will produce as much tax as $25,000,000 of tangible property, making the assessed valu - ation of the state $3,184,385,757. tA levy of 1.98 mills on the dollar will produce $6,304,320.00, this being Icient to meet the expenses of the State Government for the current 1 year and reimburse the general fund for $136,106.04 whdch was ap - propriated tfi 1923, but no levy made at that time to cover same. A levy of .16 mills will produce $477,657.86, this being sufficient to redeem all outstanding warrants, including interest which have been issued to pay deficiencies that were created in prior years. Therefore the levies for 1925 are made as follows: General Fund 1.98 mills $6,304,320.00 Redemption Fur*} .16 477.C67.S6 Capitol Ftmd .22 700,584.86 Total, 1925 Taxes 2.35 $7,482,642.72
